poem:
The Mizzlewight of Morning Fog

At greydawn’s glumble hedgerows nod,
hush-whish the morning fog;
Old whispers weft the wattle-rod—
keep clear the clammy bog.

“Keep watch,” said Gran, “for glimmers sly:
the marshborn Mizzlewight;
It mumbles mists and muddles eye,
and drinks the drifting light.”

I buckled on my whippleblade,
skrik-scrak the scabbard sang;
A sunseed lamp of amber made
went clink and clatter—clang!

Through wuzzlewind and drizzle-dell,
plop-plip the peat-path sagged;
I bided by the bramble well,
as mufflemists low dragged.

Then flubber-foot, with fluttered fronds,
croak-croak the reeds did croak;
It oozled out of umber ponds—
the Mizzlewight in cloak.

It hissed a hueless lullaloom—
hssst—my heart went splash;
I whip-whipped wide the waiting room—
skrak-skrik—one bright brash slash.

Down dropped the fogful fiend and fell,
thud-thump along the log;
Its smogskin split, unspelled the spell,
and cleared the clinging bog.

I tripped to hearth with cheerquake grin—
ha-ha! the kettles sang;
They jigged the jugs in jolly din:
ring-ding, ker-ching, ker-clang!

At goldawn’s glumble hedgerows nod,
soft hush now leaves the fog;
No whispers weft the wattle-rod—
unmurked the merry bog.

The Pathwight of the Wantway

I laced my boots with thistle-twine,

I strode back by the hedgerow's hem,
